column1: #Text=Experimental Details.- Polycrystalline samples were synthesized using a cubic-anvil-type HP apparatus and the utility of the HP synthesis technique was demonstrated elsewhere [14, 15].
#Text=The most simplest way to dope hydrogen directly into samples, it is desirable to use Er(OH)3 as a starting material.
#Text=However, Er(OH)3 is not commercially available, so that we used the indirect way (method II) descried in ref. [13] as follows.
#Text=Starting materials were powders of Fe, Fe2O3 and a precursor of ErAs.
#Text=The precursor ErAs was synthesized by reacting Er and As chips at 500 °C for 12 h and then followed by heating at 1050 °C for 12 h in an evacuated quartz tube.
#Text=The starting materials were mixed with a nominal composition of ErFeAsO1-y (y = 0.65 - 0.95), ground and pressed into pellets in a glove box filled with dry nitrogen gas.
#Text=Besides the two ErFeAsO1-y pellets, we provided three pellets with a nominal composition of LaFeAsO0.8H0.8 that were made from Fe, LaAs, As and La(OH)3.
#Text=Five pellets were simultaneously packed into a BN crucible as shown in the inset of Fig. 1, where H-free target ErFeAsO1-y pellets were sandwiched between the LaFeAsO0.8H0.8 ones.
#Text=The pellets were heated at a temperature of 1100 °C under a pressure of 5.0 ~ 5.5 GPa for 1 h.
#Text=The hydrogen ions released from the LaFeAsO0.8H0.8 pellets were expected to penetrate into the ErFeAsO1-y pellets during sample preparation.
#Text=NMR measurements suggest that the doped H locates between Fe and La sites [16].
#Text=The samples thus synthesized are abbreviated as ErFeAsO1-y(H) or Er-1111(H) hereafter.
#Text=By this technique, we obtained two Er-1111(H) samples with different nominal oxygen contents at the same time.
#Text=It should be noted that we have never obtained the Er-1111 phase without LaFeAsO0.8H0.8 pellets.
